An easy version of Yu-Gi-Oh! 20-30 cards in the main deck are quick to finish a duel for fun and strategy. Build your own deck, choose your favourite skills, character, card covers and mat. The system is easy for beginners to learn. Rush has been introduced for more than 1 year, quicker to finish and you can normal, tribute and special summon as many as allowed. There are many active players online. You can always have fun.
I wish to play with new players.

if you used to play this card game growing up, you know how fun it is. Just a wholesome card game that brings back childhood memories, for those who know. passed the game on mobile now to do the same on pc. Great game to play with coworkers on your lunch break or smoke break.
ngl i thought this will save me from the other sweat games where everything ends in one turn but sadly this one has the opposite problem, still a fun game though i hope it gets harder later on

Despite being a different format than normal Yu-Gi-Oh, this is genuinely one of the best Yu-Gi-Oh games. It has a good banlist unlike Master Duel, and it makes all your favorite old decks from the Duel Monster days actually viable for PVP. Overall, this is a great game. Easily a 4.5 out of 5.

I‚Äôve been playing Duel Links on and off since February 2017. I played mostly on iOS but recently also took advantage of the steam client. Honestly compared to other TCG games that are almost exclusively pvp oriented, this one has a good frequency of limited time pve events as well as a good amount of non-limited time pve content requiring you to do several tasks to level up each ‚Äúgate‚Äù (basically you have one per different Yu-Gi-OH iteration and they are levelled up separately). Another thing I like in this game that isn‚Äôt present in most, is each character having a set of unique abilities which give you additional things you can do in a duel apart from ‚Äújust the standard duelling actions‚Äù. This can vary from adding specific cards to your hand or deck, summoning, different attacks, ect. It adds a nice little ‚Äúextra something‚Äù. 
The format of Duel Links is different to normal Yu-Gi-Oh, in that you can summon less cards in front of you, you have less time per turn and you have less life points. Overall I think this is good, it makes for more fast paced duels. 
I will say additionaly that as far as Gatcha games go, this is one of the more f2p ones I‚Äôve encounterd. The crystals are given quite frequently for free and I was able to build many decks without spending any money. I‚Äôll put a disclaimer here by saying that when I last logged in to the game after a long period of inactivity, I noticed that they had changed the crystal currency to seperate free crystals amd paid crystals so we will have to see what happens with that but I fear this will inevitably lead to it being less f2p than before.

One of the best Yu-Gi-Oh! games ever made 
it has all characters and the soundtrack is really great
I've always enjoyed the spin-off games more than the actual. This is a perfect blend between the actual game and anime. Even though the gotcha can be frustrating at times.

The game is slowly but surely turning into Master Duel, but it's much better as of now and the new player experience is ways better. Might be a hot take, since it's not perfect, but I'd call it the best Yu-Gi-Oh game we've got

This is not Yu-Gi-Oh for beginners anymore.

This is not F2P Yu-Gi-Oh anymore.

This is not "grind for whatever deck you want" anymore.

This is not "a more balanced metagame than Master Duel" anymore.

If this doesn't bother you, Duel Links is a perfectly okay Yu-Gi-Oh! game with a limited field.  Try not to spend too much money.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links delivers a streamlined yet engaging adaptation of the long-running card game series, providing an accessible entry point for newcomers while keeping established fans invested. The mobile format suits its fast-paced structure, with duels designed to be concise without sacrificing tactical depth. Its presentation captures the spirit of the franchise, offering a nostalgic experience for those familiar with the original anime and card game. The overall tone remains energetic and inviting throughout.
Gameplay stands out through its simplified Speed Duel mechanics, making strategic battles easier to grasp while still rewarding clever deck building. Regular events, card releases and themed challenges maintain a steady sense of progression. The duel flow is responsive and polished, with well-balanced pacing that keeps matches tense yet accessible. The free-to-play model introduces some grind, but a wealth of earnable cards helps maintain fairness.
Visually, the game remains faithful to the trademark style of the franchise, with bright colours and crisp card artwork that looks excellent on mobile screens. Character models and animations add flair without overwhelming the play area. Special summon sequences and signature monster cut-ins give battles a dynamic feel. The polished interface complements the fast duel structure and remains intuitive throughout.
Overall, Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links offers a vibrant and engaging experience that successfully translates the spirit of the card game into a mobile format. Its simplified ruleset, frequent events and polished presentation create an accessible yet satisfying duelling environment. While its storytelling remains fairly light and its progression occasionally grind-heavy, the core gameplay loop remains compelling. Fans of the franchise and strategic card games alike will find plenty to enjoy.
Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links gets a 6/10.

fun game less headache than MD but the crafting system and gacha is horrendous
I'm a pretty big fan of the game. I know its a gacha game, but I'm still having fun.

Noticed my playtime was 3,333.3 hours so I'll finally say it's a great free game full of really nice QoL features that I'm still discovering to this day. It's very grindy but has a lot of things to make that grind interesting. It's also a constant brain trainer which cannot be said for most things on Steam.

I will say I'm not at all a fan of art styles like this in games(asian cartoon type stuff), but I played the card game in my teenage years and loved it so I couldn't resist trying this out and I'm glad I did.

Basically everything in the game is available for ingame currency at some point, so there isn't really pay2win unless you are using the absolute newest deck(which later becomes free, or rather available for ingame currency/tickets to get 3 copies of every card). There are also nigh endless amounts of easy or free rewards in the game to keep you progressing and building your favourite deck(s).

I'd recommend this game to anyone(just try it for a while and see what you think). Also try to experiment a bit with the game settings and clicking random buttons on the UI because there are a LOT of hidden little features that make the whole experience so much better. I'm personally a huge fan of the top down view for dueling for example, but there is far more. Auto-dueling(and auto-deckbuilding for events/farmdecks) is nice too to farm for items, which you will do a lot.

I can say the ranked duels can get pretty serious and stressful at high level play so I try to avoid that as much as possible. There are really people out there that live and breathe this game and just seem to play one deck their whole life and usually just copy decks that others are using. If you make one tiny mistake against these players or draw one wrong card it can often mean defeat.

It's clear there have been some great developers/managers at work with the game. It's built solidly and fairly from my experience. I have personally never paid money but have dueled plenty at the highest possible levels. It all depends on how you duel... not your wallet.

For what it is, I'd rate it a 8/10. One point taken away because the grind(if you want at least 3 copies of every card) is absolutely insane, and there is no auto-dueling option at the gate(where you farm many cards from 'legendary' duellists). They did relatively recently add it for events but not for all existing duellists. Another point taken off because I simply don't like the art style including some sexualised designs.

All in all it's really addictive and remains interesting with new cards and things constantly added to the game keeping things fresh while also updating older deck types to become usable again.

Very great game and close to the actual series when playing. 
I had lots of fun building my deck.
The only major Downside is in order for them to make money they kept making cards and decks where basically you lose on your very first turn. We (the normal players) have to wait 5 to 10 minute so that the opponent finish his first turn and after all that wait we are losing the game because he kicked all our defence  or whatever and wipe all our life points.
If you can get past that and play vs normal opponents, the game is actually good and I still play every now and then. And I watch the series every now and then. I grew up with Yu-Gi-Oh series
I do recommend the game it is very good. But as I said , be weary about them opponents that take 10 minutes to end his first turn and you simply lose. My advice is to just forfeit and skip to next opponent.

I‚Äôve gotten pretty bored of Yu-Gi-Oh over the past few years, mainly because of how stale and competitive the meta has become. However, Duel Links is a refreshing and well-made take on the game. It‚Äôs genuinely fun to play and captures the spirit of Yu-Gi-Oh in a more balanced way.

My only real complaint is how long it takes to get good cards. Since cards come from booster packs, luck plays a huge role, and grinding for the ones you want can take a while. Still, aside from that, Duel Links offers a great experience. The meta feels more lenient and balanced compared to Master Duel or even the physical TCG.

One of my favorite parts is being able to play as iconic anime characters like Yugi, Kaiba, and Jaden, complete with their original voice lines. There are also plenty of ways to duel: you can battle friends, face off against other players online, or take on AI duelists in the world. Completing stage missions to unlock rewards and earn new cards adds even more to do.

There‚Äôs a lot more depth to Duel Links, but that‚Äôs the core of what makes it great. Overall, it‚Äôs a fantastic and accessible way to enjoy Yu-Gi-Oh again. Highly recommended.

real life sucks

Been playing this game on and off again almost since it first came out. This is one of the free yugioh games on the market so the entrypoint is easy for newcomers to the series or those that don't have alot of money to spend. Duel links while is a fun game, does feel like a very 'diet' version of the actual game. There are things that are exclusive to duel links such as their own unique cards, sometimes they changed the effects of pre existing cards, and characters can acquire skills to use in duels which do various things. Another main difference is the smaller zones for cards, 3 for spell and trap and 3 for monsters (or 4ish? if you summon something from the extra deck) instead of the usual 5 that alongside the life points being 4000 for each player means the duels last alot shorter then your normal average match would.  While I don't think these are necasarily bad things, especially since duel links is also a mobile game which caters to the faster duels, it is something to be aware of. The whole time you are playing this, it does feel like you're not getting the full true experience. The game has many events that pop up every now and then, and various playable characters from alot of (if not all)  the different animes, even some of the less popular side characters that only showed up for an episode or two. Ultimately this game is very good and offers alot of fanservice but it's not perfect and does have it's  flaws. Personally I wish you could use whatever cards you wanted to against the A.I and have it just  be  restricted during PvP like how Legacy of the Duelist works.

Great game. Has a steep learning curve for new players (particularly those not familiar with the Yu-Gi-Oh franchise), but learning and persevering will be worth it. Collecting new cards and building new decks somehow still remains captivating even after 4000+ hours of playtime.
Would really love to see additional uses for Gold though. It's just not a useful commodity for veteran players (I myself have accumulated over 21 million gold). Perhaps allowing veteran players to trade Gold for Gems / Dream Tickets could be the answer.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links is a fantastic mix of nostalgia and strategy. Playing as Yugi, Kaiba, and other classic characters with their original voices makes duels feel authentic. The controls are easy for beginners, but deck-building and ranked matches keep things challenging for veterans. Dynamic monster animations and constant new card updates make it super addictive.

Anyone remember Yugioh Bam? Like, the Facebook Yugioh Bam?

That game walked so this one can run. If you like Gacha and Yugioh, this scratches an itch that lasted me a good week or two, but might last you a bit longer if you're really into it.

Especially so If you're into GOAT format or really like the anime, as this one lets you assign characters from all the animes to each deck, each with their own voicelines, but also their own special abilities that make older, weaker archetypes viable. Not to mention a lot of the more modern floodgatey stuff isn't in this game.

So, If you want to play Yugioh and Master Duel scares you, try this.

negative.review: Used to love this game but similar to Master Duel this is a game that makes me hate myself for the  idea of spending time and money on a franchise based solely on sentiment. I could bring up multiple reasons I won't recommend this to others but I'll stick with the most recent. They used to have the ability to buy packs/decks/cosmetics etc for cash and you could see the price directly however they have switched to another currency thereby clouding how much you actually spend. You now have to take the extra step to calculate how much you will spend and even if the prices now are equal to what they would have been otherwise it opens the door for them to later increase the cost so that you don't realize how much you are spending. This is not uncommon in today's games but I personally find this shady and vile for any company to do. To top it off Yugioh is rife with controversy these days at every level. Ocg, Tcg, Master Duel and Duel Links and the majority of it can be traced to corporate greed and shareholder profits being placed so far above the consumer as to be downright insulting. I will likely play this sporadically much like Master Duel without spending money ever again on it until one day I realize my love for the franchise has finally died after having been diminished for years much like my love for games like world of warcraft.

I remember back when this was the funny anime card game now it's just master duel with 2 less zones and cheat skills.
also gotta say I love that auto battle AI will summon a 0 attack point tuner from my hand in attack position then proceed to end turn instead of synchro summoning with it causing me to lose, or when I have lethal on board but the auto duel AI decides that I need to link into Knightmare unicorn and not even activate its effect.

Trash gatcha game with terrible monetization, play master duel instead, game was fun when it was old yugioh formats with some minor buffs to anime decks, now it's an abusive trash skill simulator that will wring you dry just to play the same shit you're playing in master duel but with more limitations,

Play any other card g ame.

As someone who has played this game FOR SO LONG... No. It's not a good game. It's sadly the best "Anime" Yu-Gi-Oh game (the other is Legacy but both inferior to Tag Force) but Konami made it so PAY-TO-WIN that it doesn't feel worth playing. I had my ups and downs but this year in 2025 was the worse era for this game. It became Skill Links (basically you need a broken skill to compete), pay real money to get what you need and the meta is unfair. This game is very unfriendly to Free-To-Play users.

If you want to play this "game", give it a try... but you'll slowly not enjoy it. Trust me, I will uninstall soon.

A friend asked me to download this game as he has gotten back into Yu-Gi-Oh, so I did.
Knowing from my experience with Master Duel with him, the download is in-game, not Steam, so I loaded the game up. Then I went through the tutorial. It had me play as either Yugi or Kaiba as they duel each other. It was very basic and the voice acting was very stiff, to the point where I thought they were using AI.

Then it took me to Duel World and told me I had to duel someone else, but I was allowed to skip it. This whole time, I am thinking, "Hey, when can I set the game to fullscreen? I'm stuck in windowed mode."
By the time I got to a menu, it wouldn't let me click on the settings and made me do duels first. 

After skipping the first duel, it had me go into a mission tab and redeem points that I had to use to buy come cards. Then it started a cutscene that introduced Joey Wheeler into the game. Then it told me I had to redeem more points and do more tutorials before letting me do anything else. All the while, I am still stuck in windowed mode.

That's when I stopped. I have fond memories of Yu-Gi-Oh as a kid, but That was over 20 years ago. I simply don't care anymore, and I definitely don't care enough to play this PC port of a phone game.
they tied to pull a nintendo and sue cygames uma musume for game mechanics

I am posting a review of this game today after nearly 600 hours to say that while the game is good, a recent change has made it too predatory and disrespectful to be considers so, for me, any more.

The developers have recently introduced Crystals (yet another of 14 or so different metacurrencies) whose sole purpose is to hide the real-world value of what is being spent.

Prior to this update; pack prices were very clear and in readable currency (e.g ¬£3.99). Now they are '300 Crystals' and of course you cannot purchase exactly 300 crystals.

This is called currency obfuscation and is explicitly designed to make the player pay more and have leftovers to tempt them into paying more still.

I do not support or respect it and thus will no longer spend any money on this game. I recommend anyone with an ounce of dignity also boycott any spending in this game.

You CAN still play against the AI, but you'll miss a ton of stuff that you can only get in PVP.
And I hear Master Duel is even worse.

Despite its initial promise as a streamlined and mobile-friendly adaptation of the classic trading card game, Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links has unfortunately devolved into a frustratingly unbalanced and increasingly predatory experience. I cannot in good faith recommend this title to prospective players.

The game‚Äôs progression model is overwhelmingly pay-to-win, with competitive viability largely contingent on either substantial monetary investment or an exhausting grind for in-game gems. Acquiring essential cards requires either spending considerable sums or dedicating countless hours to repetitive farming‚Äîa system that disincentivizes casual engagement and alienates newcomers.

Ranked play, which should be the pinnacle of competitive enjoyment, is marred by glacial pacing and excessively convoluted deck strategies. Many players spend inordinate amounts of time executing combo-heavy sequences, reducing the opponent to a passive spectator. Furthermore, success is virtually unattainable without aligning oneself with the current meta, as any deviation is swiftly punished.

Events, once a potential highlight, have descended into monotonous repetition. The lack of innovation or meaningful variety underscores the developers‚Äô reliance on recycled content rather than offering players fresh challenges.

Compounding these issues is the ephemeral nature of investments: decks that require significant time or money to assemble are often rendered obsolete by rapid restrictions or the release of more powerful archetypes. This treadmill ensures that players are perpetually chasing relevance while rarely feeling rewarded.

Lastly, the Skill system, once intended to enhance strategic depth, has become an overbearing mechanic that frequently dictates the flow of duels. Skills often act as automatic combo enablers or direct win conditions, eliminating meaningful counterplay and stripping away genuine tactical decision-making.

In sum, while Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links retains a nostalgic veneer and remains accessible on a surface level, its underlying design fosters frustration, monotony, and a near-compulsory reliance on financial investment. The game exemplifies the pitfalls of a free-to-play ecosystem that prioritizes monetization over long-term player satisfaction.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links is best avoided by those seeking a fair, engaging, or enduring card game experience.

Duel Links is such an interesting and unique spin on the base YGO game. At its core the game is a lighter version of TCG, with more consistent and quicker games. Meta is also very interesting to say, quite unique decks that seem fun to play. Addition of skills is really a double edged sword, on one hand they do make some archetypes actually work, they also make your deck extremely consistent (especially nowdays) which results in games often feeling monotonous. 

Where the problem lies is that the game is extremely expensive and grindy. Skills are often locked behind a grindy time limited event. Cards are obtained through literal gacha, with no option to craft them, and inherently because of how YGO works, no replacements. Sometimes packs cannot even be opened for in game currency but need to be purchased with money and cards inside are not obtainable any other way (the true p2w). 

Release of Master Duel also killed a huge chunk of the player base, although the whales still keep the lights on. It is quite sad to think of what the game could have been. So yeah, game play good, but monetization kills it

3/10

Yu gi oh Duel Links suffers from the same problems Yu GI Oh has in general:

Most games can be won within 1-4 turns with cookie cutter builds. When they introduced the latest cards, it was no longer really about strategy. Just learning the combos and what other cookie cutters came out to counter yours. But this isn't restricted to Yu Gi Oh Only, games like Pokemon TCG Pocket have this same problem. Duel Links just had a time where it didn't have this problem.

We know the reasoning behind this is because better cards mean more sales though, thats sort of a given with most tcg.

The problem with Yu Gi Oh Duel Links though, is the predatory nature of gacha to obtain the latest cards to make the latest decks. Sure you can run with a Maldoche Deck and get away with some games, but if you are looking to make a Live Twin Deck, it'll take a lot of grinding to get the currency to spam the packs.

Because there is no restrictions on modes or pvp, you can basically go ham.

Everything designed around this game was made to waste your time and money, like any other gacha. Everything you do feels like a chore and revolves around grinding for whatever you need, whether it's a character you want, a skill for said character, or cards and staples necessary to improve your deck. Touching more on the process behind obtaining certain cards you'll need when making a deck, you'll have a few options for when you try and get them. Firstly, if the card is a level up reward from a certain character, you'll be forced to grind using that specific character in order to gain enough exp and levels for said card. The cpus you'll find around the world are extremely repetitive and limited. It's possible to spend hours up to days and in some cases even weeks trying to get whatever you need for your deck, grinding endlessly against the same cardboard cutout c*ck heads who wear the most basic and uninspiring outfits known to man, looking like the type of people you'd see on those job hiring posters around public areas talking about some "Join today! We're looking for people like you, who have the skills to dig in your ass and pick the pubes out of your crack". Many of the important cards and staples used for basic combos in decks are stashed away in mini boxes that you'll have to spend in-game currency on just for a chance at getting whatever you're looking for. Not to mention those mini boxes are bloated with other cards of the same rarity that are useless or completely unrelated that you'll probably never end up using, added in just to make the pulling rates for those cards lower. If you end up running out of currency from trying to pull on the mini box with the cards you want, either you'll have to grind against the previously stated cpus for a portion of that currency so small it would make even a poor and starving victorian child ungrateful, or give into what the developers WANT you to do and spend real life money yay!!! All so that you can PLAY THE GAME LESS. Another atrocious example of the game's design are character skills. Character skills are basically abilities you can use during the duel by fulfilling certain requirements within that duel or activate immediately upon starting. Some of these skills can straight up give you cards for free, cards that you didn't even have in your deck, opening up a whole new world of bullsh*t waiting to happen. Skills are such a huge monopoly in the game that in many cases that you might not be building decks that can play on their own without having to use them, you'll be building decks AROUND the skills in the game. When dueling online it doesn't feel like you're using any real strategy to outwit your opponent, using your deck's capabilities to their fullest in order to lock down on that win, it feels like who can activate their skills first in order to gain an unfair advantage and set up their endgame boards on turn one. 

Some of the few positives I do hold for this game are in its concepts and vibe. This game is a very simplistic and much more laid back version of Yugioh's main tcg counterpart. You'll usually be playing a 20 card deck, half of what the minimum is for regular Yugioh and there are only three monster and spell/trap zones available versus the usual six. Games go by so much quicker than how long they'd usually take in real life and offers newer players trying to get into the franchise a a warmer welcome to the game and its mechanics. The rest of my praise goes to being able to play as the characters from the Anime. There are so many god d*mn characters that you can play as in the game, all with their own voicelines and card animations. No matter how basic the voicelines may be after hearing them so many times, I still find them adding that little charm that makes the game worth playing sometimes. In the modern day and age of Yugioh games, not many, if any at all, offer you to play the actual characters from the series. Mostly having a main focus on the tcg aspects rather than fan service, making Duel Links one of the few games that does which I find that it makes the game stand out more and gives the players something that would be hard to find anywhere else.

Overall, I think this game is a sh*tty titty piece of ass that wants to eat your money and offers a boring experience in return, involving endless grinding just to build and complete a deck to eventually use in online play where your opponent might win just because they picked a character with a better skill than you that makes your efforts completely useless. Although the game still offers you an experience that you can't find in many other places, being able to play as your favorite characters from the Manga and Anime in a nice and much more simplistic style of the physical card game.

Unfortunately another pay to win game. As a new player in 2025 and a returning play from early 2000s. I can say the meta decks are clearly priced to make you feel like you have to spend money and there are a plenty of resources online describing the F2P grind. And it is grindy. For example those who like to know more, If you want to buy a pack of cards for a deck with your rewards. Great idea. lots of staples to be had early on. Unless they are on say 5 to 10 packs depending what box may sent you back 1000 crystals ok no big deal. As you progress you will realize just how few crystals they give you for any sort of reward. 10 to 50 being the majority. No revist your previous purchase early on. Is it worth playing if you like the game Yes surely you will build a fun deck or comp one and have some good fun. Is it designed to make you think you have to spend money. YES. Dont do it. Use AI to build a good deck with your early rewards I ended up with a utopia deck. Dont blindly spend a penny until they learn a lesson like all others. Great game well designed good graphics but too much predatory nonsense.

I just wanted to play some old-school Yu-Gi-Oh online, but Duel Links has become a complete mess. The title screen alone bombards you with menus, pop-ups, and way too many currencies. I swear there are at least five different ones, and I still don‚Äôt even know what half of them do. Everything feels overcomplicated for no reason.

Then you get into a duel and it‚Äôs even worse. Every single card has three or more effects, chains go on forever, and it‚Äôs impossible to keep track of what‚Äôs happening. I stopped playing in real life around the XyZ era, and coming back now just feels like stepping into chaos.
Paid currency? After all these years? Greedy greedy devs. The new system is designed to squeeze even more cash out of the now diminshing fan base. What an own goal.

Step two - Waiting for your opponent to Synchro, Xyx, Pendulum, Special, Normal, Tribute, Activate, Negate, Set... forgot the rest because I was making a coffee

Step three - Lose without knowing until you analyse and realise "I don't have time for that"

Prior to this update; pack prices were very clear and in readable currency (e.g ¬£3.99). Now they are '300 Crystals' and of course you cannot purchase exactly 300 crystals.

I do not support or respect it and thus will no longer spend any money on this game. I recommend anyone with an ounce of dignity also boycott any spending in this game.

655 hours in and PVP is unplayable. Go first or lose. Now there are about a dozen FTK decks that lock you out of everything and give +4 cards per use of skill. And Konami's response is to ban cards that you spent resources on instead of nerfing their ridiculous, broken skills.
You CAN still play against the AI, but you'll miss a ton of stuff that you can only get in PVP.

Used to love this game but similar to Master Duel this is a game that makes me hate myself for the  idea of spending time and money on a franchise based solely on sentiment. I could bring up multiple reasons I won't recommend this to others but I'll stick with the most recent. They used to have the ability to buy packs/decks/cosmetics etc for cash and you could see the price directly however they have switched to another currency thereby clouding how much you actually spend. You now have to take the extra step to calculate how much you will spend and even if the prices now are equal to what they would have been otherwise it opens the door for them to later increase the cost so that you don't realize how much you are spending. This is not uncommon in today's games but I personally find this shady and vile for any company to do. To top it off Yugioh is rife with controversy these days at every level. Ocg, Tcg, Master Duel and Duel Links and the majority of it can be traced to corporate greed and shareholder profits being placed so far above the consumer as to be downright insulting. I will likely play this sporadically much like Master Duel without spending money ever again on it until one day I realize my love for the franchise has finally died after having been diminished for years much like my love for games like world of warcraft.

also gotta say I love that auto battle AI will summon a 0 attack point tuner from my hand in attack position then proceed to end turn instead of synchro summoning with it causing me to lose, or when I have lethal on board but the auto duel AI decides that I need to link into Knightmare unicorn and not even activate its effect.

Despite its initial promise as a streamlined and mobile-friendly adaptation of the classic trading card game, Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links has unfortunately devolved into a frustratingly unbalanced and increasingly predatory experience. I cannot in good faith recommend this title to prospective players.

The game‚Äôs progression model is overwhelmingly pay-to-win, with competitive viability largely contingent on either substantial monetary investment or an exhausting grind for in-game gems. Acquiring essential cards requires either spending considerable sums or dedicating countless hours to repetitive farming‚Äîa system that disincentivizes casual engagement and alienates newcomers.

Ranked play, which should be the pinnacle of competitive enjoyment, is marred by glacial pacing and excessively convoluted deck strategies. Many players spend inordinate amounts of time executing combo-heavy sequences, reducing the opponent to a passive spectator. Furthermore, success is virtually unattainable without aligning oneself with the current meta, as any deviation is swiftly punished.

Events, once a potential highlight, have descended into monotonous repetition. The lack of innovation or meaningful variety underscores the developers‚Äô reliance on recycled content rather than offering players fresh challenges.

Compounding these issues is the ephemeral nature of investments: decks that require significant time or money to assemble are often rendered obsolete by rapid restrictions or the release of more powerful archetypes. This treadmill ensures that players are perpetually chasing relevance while rarely feeling rewarded.

Lastly, the Skill system, once intended to enhance strategic depth, has become an overbearing mechanic that frequently dictates the flow of duels. Skills often act as automatic combo enablers or direct win conditions, eliminating meaningful counterplay and stripping away genuine tactical decision-making.

In sum, while Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links retains a nostalgic veneer and remains accessible on a surface level, its underlying design fosters frustration, monotony, and a near-compulsory reliance on financial investment. The game exemplifies the pitfalls of a free-to-play ecosystem that prioritizes monetization over long-term player satisfaction.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Links is best avoided by those seeking a fair, engaging, or enduring card game experience.

Duel Links is such an interesting and unique spin on the base YGO game. At its core the game is a lighter version of TCG, with more consistent and quicker games. Meta is also very interesting to say, quite unique decks that seem fun to play. Addition of skills is really a double edged sword, on one hand they do make some archetypes actually work, they also make your deck extremely consistent (especially nowdays) which results in games often feeling monotonous. 

Where the problem lies is that the game is extremely expensive and grindy. Skills are often locked behind a grindy time limited event. Cards are obtained through literal gacha, with no option to craft them, and inherently because of how YGO works, no replacements. Sometimes packs cannot even be opened for in game currency but need to be purchased with money and cards inside are not obtainable any other way (the true p2w). 

Release of Master Duel also killed a huge chunk of the player base, although the whales still keep the lights on. It is quite sad to think of what the game could have been. So yeah, game play good, but monetization kills it

3/10

As someone who has played this game FOR SO LONG... No. It's not a good game. It's sadly the best "Anime" Yu-Gi-Oh game (the other is Legacy but both inferior to Tag Force) but Konami made it so PAY-TO-WIN that it doesn't feel worth playing. I had my ups and downs but this year in 2025 was the worse era for this game. It became Skill Links (basically you need a broken skill to compete), pay real money to get what you need and the meta is unfair. This game is very unfriendly to Free-To-Play users.

If you want to play this "game", give it a try... but you'll slowly not enjoy it. Trust me, I will uninstall soon.

A friend asked me to download this game as he has gotten back into Yu-Gi-Oh, so I did.
Knowing from my experience with Master Duel with him, the download is in-game, not Steam, so I loaded the game up. Then I went through the tutorial. It had me play as either Yugi or Kaiba as they duel each other. It was very basic and the voice acting was very stiff, to the point where I thought they were using AI.

Then it took me to Duel World and told me I had to duel someone else, but I was allowed to skip it. This whole time, I am thinking, "Hey, when can I set the game to fullscreen? I'm stuck in windowed mode."
By the time I got to a menu, it wouldn't let me click on the settings and made me do duels first. 

After skipping the first duel, it had me go into a mission tab and redeem points that I had to use to buy come cards. Then it started a cutscene that introduced Joey Wheeler into the game. Then it told me I had to redeem more points and do more tutorials before letting me do anything else. All the while, I am still stuck in windowed mode.

That's when I stopped. I have fond memories of Yu-Gi-Oh as a kid, but That was over 20 years ago. I simply don't care anymore, and I definitely don't care enough to play this PC port of a phone game.

Yu gi oh Duel Links suffers from the same problems Yu GI Oh has in general:

Most games can be won within 1-4 turns with cookie cutter builds. When they introduced the latest cards, it was no longer really about strategy. Just learning the combos and what other cookie cutters came out to counter yours. But this isn't restricted to Yu Gi Oh Only, games like Pokemon TCG Pocket have this same problem. Duel Links just had a time where it didn't have this problem.

We know the reasoning behind this is because better cards mean more sales though, thats sort of a given with most tcg.

The problem with Yu Gi Oh Duel Links though, is the predatory nature of gacha to obtain the latest cards to make the latest decks. Sure you can run with a Maldoche Deck and get away with some games, but if you are looking to make a Live Twin Deck, it'll take a lot of grinding to get the currency to spam the packs.

Because there is no restrictions on modes or pvp, you can basically go ham.
